title: Why are 5G phones necessary? Isn't 4G fast enough? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hi Now I'll admit I don't know a lot about 5G. There will be other answers I expect. Here's what I'm thinking though… For almost all phone users, you won't notice the difference with 5G. What are you doing on your phone now that needs more bandwidth or lower latency? For most urban users 4G bandwidth is sufficient for viewing video on a mobile. It seems that augmented or virtual reality apps will benefit from lower latency, to allow real time response to user location and movement. But the AR /VR tech and user base is yet to mature. The need for 5G reminds me of the early days of 3G. This was a tech in need of a compelling application. From 2001 to 2005 that compelling application didn't exist. There were poor attempts at sport streaming of highlights, but overall most users didn't want to pay the premium for a patchy service. Then the iPhone came along, enough said. 4G was needed to provide even more bandwidth for all the smart phones in use. The tech was catching up with user demand. Even further back we could argue that 2G was needed because 1G was not keeping up with demand. Again tech catching up. Perhaps we'll see computing power for mobile applications shift to the cloud. So the connection between the remote processing and the local user will have to step up. That's speculation. 5G does more though that you may not notice as a mobile user: Wireless broadband to the home. No need for DSL or fibre. Gigabit speeds from neighbourhood boxes into homes. Autonomous vehicles. The need to locate and control thousands of vehicles continuously and immediately. Smart cities. Monitoring and controlling tens of thousands of sensors. Not necessarily large amounts of data from each individual end point, but the need to have vast numbers of devices online simultaneously. It'll be an interesting time and I hope the applications catch up to use the communication capability that will be around. For some other background have a read of the 5G paper from NZ telco Spark. https://www.sparknz.co.nz/content/dam/SparkNZ/pdf-documents/5G%20Briefing%20document.pdf

Unfortunately 4G isn't fast enough in all countries. My country has the slowest 4G LTE speeds in the world. India Found Again to have Slowest 4G LTE Speeds in the World. I've always faced lag and buffering issues on Indian 4G LTE while trying to live stream a channel. Whereas my internet friends in Canada, Netherlands and even Vietnam didn't face any issue streaming the same. I have become so irritated with Indian LTE speeds that the only reason strong enough to compell me to leave this nation is slow internet. I can manage rest all problems. Therefore, I am eagerly waiting for 5G technology to launch and 5G phones to come in the market. My hands are itching to buy a 5G powered smartphone. 5G is definitely gonna solve the lag and buffering problem while streaming anything live. 5G data will also be cheaper so I can use much more data than today. My average data usage LTE+Wifi crosses 100 GB per month usually. 5G would probably increase the data usage threefold. Moreover, it's said that 5G will bring Internet of Things where devices can interact with each other. 5G phones would help us communicate with other electronic devices directly and things would become easier. It's also said that 5G will help develop smart cities. Sounds good. But it seems that I won't be able to use it for the next four years. India aims to roll out 5G network by 2022: Report.

It is not about “not fast enough”. And 5G is not only about speed, although this is the dominant theme in the public perception. There is also a “narrowband” section of 5G, with applications in digitized industry and things like e-health, critical infrastructure and autonomous driving. What counts here is high reliability, much more than speed. Also 5G provides answers to the ongoing densification of urban life, with many phones and devices in a small area. 5G NR (New Radio) provides massive increase of data density. And also energy efficiency is a big theme. ICT industry today already has a carbon footprint equivalent to the international aviation industry. With a 1000 time increase of data volumes current technology would lead straight into a disaster. So 5G puts a lot of focus on massive increase of energy efficiency (even lower transmission power than 4G and predecessors, higher spectrum efficiency, slicing and service chaining of networks to re-use idle components, support of cloud solutions, and and and).

You asked: Why are 5G phones necessary? Isn't 4G fast enough? No, 4G is not fast enough. In many places, the 4G network is so overloaded with users that it is painful to use. 150Mbit/s seem really fast unt you have 1000 people trying to use it all at once (and each can only get 150kbit/s as a result. What, you didn't foolishly think that was 150Mbit/s per person, did you?)

This is a loaded question. 5G is faster and has lower latency, enabling things that aren’t possible with 4G. Integration with the Internet of Things, for instance. Whether or not that is necessary is a judgment call based on your opinion and needs. No question that 5G is an advancement in technological capability.

While higher data rates get all the attenton, there are other reasons for 5G introduction, such as a unifiying network architecture, and repalcing the aging but still very necessary 2G(!!!) infrastructure Regarding the effective data rate, an overloaded 5G network will not do better as a overloaded 4G network, so please separate ‘miracles’ from realty
Just to receive and make phone calls and receive texts, nothing more involved than 2G is necessary. I still use a venerable Nokia 3310. Battery life between charges is ~ 5 days too
Did not say that 5G is required .There are still a lot of non-intelligent machines available. 5G applications are more connected and used by smart hardware outside the mobile phone.

No doubt, 4G is good but is maxing out its capacity to onboard all of the new challenges technology is throwing at it. The following article provides an insight into why 5G is the answer to the need for speed: 5G NETWORK-A COMPLETE GUIDE TO UNDERSTANDING THE PLANET’S NEWEST TECHNOLOGY
